perturbation.original_text: 8.1 Without prejudice to any term and condition under this Agreement, the Company shall maintain in force, at all times during the Term and [*****], at its own costs and expenses, with insurers of internationally recognized reputation reasonably acceptable to the Repairer, insurances in accordance with industry standards with respect to the undertakings of the Company in Clause 15 ("Liability and Indemnity") of this Agreement including: (i) Aircraft Hull and Spares All Risks Insurances (including, to the extent usually available war and allied perils); and, (ii) Comprehensive General Third Party Legal Liability and Aircraft Passengers and Third Party Legal Liability Insurance in respect of incidents involving Aircraft to the extent usually available, having a Combined Single Limit of not less than [*****] any one occurrence; and, (iii) Employer's liability insurance; and, (iv) Repairer's values to be insured, including: - Lease of Stock (Exhibit 8 Clause 2.2) and Advanced Pool Service (Exhibit 15): the Items of the Stock shall be insured by theCompany under Spares All Risk Insurance for not less than the full replacement value; and, - Main Elements Service (Exhibit 11): each Spare Main Element to be delivered by the Repairer to the Company shall be insured by the Company, for not less than its full replacement value, under the Hull Insurance when installed on the Aircraft in addition to the agreed value of such Aircraft and under the Spares All Risk Insurance while in Stock prior to attachment or following removal and replacement from the Aircraft, including transportation to and from the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.1 Without prejudice to any term and condition under this Agreement, the Company should consider maintaining insurances. The Company should make good-faith efforts at its own costs and expenses, with insurers, to obtain aviation insurances as it deems appropriate to meet its business needs. Such insurance *may* include: (i) Aircraft Hull and Spares All Risks Insurances; (ii) Comprehensive General Third Party Legal Liability and Aircraft Passengers and Third Party Legal Liability Insurance in respect of incidents involving Aircraft; (iii) Employer's liability insurance; and (iv) Repairer's values *may* be insured, including: - Lease of Stock (Exhibit 8 Clause 2.2) and Advanced Pool Service (Exhibit 15): the Items of the Stock *might* be insured by the Company under Spares All Risk Insurance; and - Main Elements Service (Exhibit 11): each Spare Main Element to be delivered by the Repairer to the Company *could* be insured by the Company under the Hull Insurance or the Spares All Risk Insurance.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'shall maintain' to 'should consider maintaining' and 'should make good-faith efforts', and other similar changes, the mandatory obligation to maintain specific insurance coverage is weakened. The use of 'may,' 'might,' and 'could' makes the insurance requirements discretionary rather than obligatory, which contradicts Brazilian Aviation Regulations, which may require certain minimum insurance coverage for aircraft operations and maintenance agreements. This introduces ambiguity and could lead to non-compliance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazilian Aviation Regulations (likely ANAC regulations regarding mandatory insurance coverage for aviation operations)

perturbation.original_text: 16.1 Termination events: without prejudice to any other rights under this Agreement and/or at Law, either Party shall be entitled to terminate all or part of this Agreement by Notice of termination, as per Clauses 16.4 ("Termination procedure") and 16.6 ("Consequences of termination"), in the following events: a) Insolvency: the other Party becomes insolvent or goes into liquidation or ceases paying its debts as they fall due or makes an assignment for the benefit of creditors or if such Party being a limited Company passes a resolution for its winding up or if a petition for its winding up is presented or it files for protection from its creditors under any applicable Law relating to bankruptcy or insolvency or any analogous event in any jurisdiction shall take place; and/or b) Default: the other Party is in Default and does not remedy the same within [*****], or such extended period granted by the non-defaulting Party, from Notice of default specifying the failure and requiring the remedy of such, from the non-defaulting Party. For the purpose of this Clause 16.1.b), will be deemed as material obligations under this Agreement, without the following being exhaustive: (i) the compliance by the Company with any of its payment obligations; (ii) the compliance by the Company with the provisions of Clause 17 ("Conditions precedent") of this Agreement; (iii) the operation by the Company of at least one (1) Aircraft; (iv) the use by the Company of any Item, delivered by the Repairer to the Company pursuant to Exhibits 8 ("Lease of the Stock"), 9 ("Spare parts standard exchange Service"), 10 ("LRU repair Service"), 11 ("Main Elements Services") and 15 ("Advanced Pool Stock") exclusively on Aircraft and to benefit of the Parties; (v) the return by the Company to the Repairer of any unserviceable Item which should be exclusively removed from an Aircraft; (vi) the compliance by the Repairer with its Delivery obligations; (vii) the compliance by the Parties with any of the insurance obligations as per Clause 8 ("Insurances") of this Agreement; (viii) the compliance by either Party with any other of its obligations which by its nature and/or context is intended to be material.
perturbation.changed_text: 16.1 Termination events: without prejudice to any other rights under this Agreement and/or at Law, either Party *may* be entitled to consider terminating all or part of this Agreement. The following *could* be potential termination events: a) Insolvency: if something resembling insolvency occurs; and/or b) Default: if the other Party is *arguably* in Default and *maybe* doesn't remedy it. Whether a party is in default will be subject to good-faith negotiation. For the purpose of this Clause 16.1.b), *potentially* material obligations under this Agreement could include: (i) making some payments; (ii) some compliance with Clause 17; (iii) operating *an* Aircraft; (iv) using Items delivered by the Repairer *somehow*; (v) returning *something* to the Repairer; (vi) attempting to meet Delivery obligations; (vii) *thinking about* compliance with insurance obligations; (viii) *generally trying* to meet other obligations.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces significant ambiguity into the termination clause. Replacing 'shall be entitled to terminate' with 'may be entitled to consider terminating' makes the right to terminate discretionary. The use of vague terms like 'something resembling insolvency,' 'arguably in Default,' 'maybe doesn't remedy it,' 'making some payments,' 'some compliance with Clause 17,' and 'generally trying to meet other obligations' makes it difficult to determine what constitutes a valid reason for termination. By creating ambiguity around the definition of default and the obligations of each party, this change could render the termination clause unenforceable under New York law, where contracts require clear and definite terms.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Obligations Law ยง 5-701 (Statute of Frauds) requiring contracts to have clear and definite terms

perturbation.original_text: 5.3.1.2 During the Term, the Company shall: (i) operate and maintain the Aircraft in compliance with all applicable technical documentation and any otherinstructions issued by ATR and the OEM; and, (ii) remove and install LRUs and Main Elements from and on Aircraft; and, (iii) comply with any AD, and order such incorporation or modifications from the Repairer; and consequently manage the update of Aircraft, LRUs and Main Elements mandatory or regulatory technical notices and log books and deliver to the Repairer a copy of such documentation upon each maintenance event or upon Repairer's request; and, (iv) promptly inform the Repairer in case the Company or their insurer intends to attend any LRU or Main Element tear-down at the Repair Shop; and, (v) provide the Repairer not later than the tenth (10t h) Day of each Month with an activity report relating to each Aircraft and each Main Element serial number, and containing at least FH and Cycles performed during the preceding Month, the TSN, CSN, TSO, CSO, and the removals/installations events during such Month; and, (vi) preserve the Aircraft, any Main Elements and/or any and all sub-assemblies in accordance with the AMM in caseany Aircraft is temporarily unused by the Company for any reason whatsoever.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.3.1.2 During the Term, the Company should: (i) generally operate and maintain the Aircraft with regard to technical documentation; and, (ii) handle LRUs and Main Elements; and, (iii) consider Airworthiness Directives; and, (iv) let the Repairer know if the Company or its insurer is thinking about attending a tear-down; and, (v) try to provide an activity report monthly, with *some* information; and, (vi) keep the Aircraft in *reasonable* condition in accordance with *some* Aircraft Maintenance Manual, if it's not being used.
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes clear obligations for the Company regarding aircraft maintenance and reporting. By changing 'shall' to 'should,' and adding terms like 'generally,' 'with regard to,' 'consider,' 'thinking about,' 'try to,' 'some information,' and 'reasonable condition,' the modified text weakens these obligations and introduces significant ambiguity. This ambiguity directly undermines the clear maintenance standards mandated by the Brazilian Civil Aviation Authority (ANAC), as well as EASA and FAA regulations, rendering the company's maintenance responsibilities vague and difficult to enforce.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazilian Civil Aviation Regulations (ANAC standards on Aircraft Maintenance); EASA/FAA regulations
